search_result.title: Reno restaurants: 12 new eateries open fall 2018
search_result.text:
Here are the latest dispatches from the Reno restaurant front, with openings across the city. There's elevated pub food in the Northwest, a wine shop pioneer taking the pours to Midtown, New Orleans plates, South Reno Vietnamese and more.

Some of the restaurants have appeared in previous round-ups of places that were underway but not yet doing business. These spots are listed again now they've officially debuted.

MORE:Gigaflavor: Tesla brings in local food to feed the Gigafactory

(Another round-up in the weeks ahead will cover some new restaurants not mentioned here.)

Still in the running for potential opening in 2018: Ruth's Chris Steakhouse in the Silver Legacy, the new South Reno location for Zagol Ethiopian Cuisine (after a move from East Fourth Street, thank God), and Willies Pasta Shop in Midtown (from the owners of LuLou's and Kauboi Izakaya).

____________

ĂN - ASIAN KITCHEN & BAR, 7499 Longley Lane, 775-852-6320

Ăn is the Vietnamese word for "to eat." The restaurant inhabits the soaring, architecturally distinctive wedge on Longley Lane n South Reno that, for many years, housed Cafe de Thai (now in Midtown; see below).

Owners Tony Tran and Ken Huynh also own Vietnamese restaurants in Gardnerville and at Lake Tahoe. In Reno, they've refashioned the interior of the restaurant, doing away with the waterfall and installing custom booths, among other things.

The menu offers pho, yes, but also several other soups like hot and sour, Vietnamese udon and spicy tom yum (in a nod to Thailand), as well as banh mi, clay pot dishes and sizzling meat or seafood platters.

____________

BABA'S EATS & ALES, 6148 Mae Anne Ave., 775-470-8201

Baba's Eats & Ales is in the same Northwest Reno center as Bangkok Cuisine Express (and lies down the hill from the Robb Drive center that houses Jimmy John's and Casa Grande).

The menu features starters like crisp Brussels sprouts and local honey sausage, soups and salads (the kitchen sink salad seems worth a try), burgers and sandwiches, and main courses like smothered pork chops and vegan baked spaghetti squash.

There's also a children's menu (a smart move for the family-centric Northwest.)

____________

BRAUHAUS 701, 713 S. Virginia St., 775-384-6756

Brauhaus 701, inspired by German beer halls, joins JoStella Coffee Co. in St. Lawrence Commons, a partnership between Tolles Development and Marmot Properties at the corner of Saint Lawrence Avenue and South Virginia Street in Midtown Reno.

Brauhaus occupies the former Good Luck Macbeth theater. The menu runs to pretzels, sausage boards (on the one hand), vegan tacos and vegetable boards (on the other), and a nicely edited list of 20 local, regional, national and international craft beers.

____________

CAFE DE THAI RESTAURANT & BAR, 760 S. Virginia St., 775-829-8424

For many years, Café de Thai occupied a sleek space on Longley Lane complete with indoor waterfall. The restaurant was the first in Reno to offer a modern take on Thai food (and one of the first local spots to serve craft cocktails).

Cut to: fall 2018, and Café de Thai Restaurant & Bar has recently moved to the Sticks development in Midtown Reno (just across the courtyard from the new Whispering Vine; see below).

At lunch, try the crisp corn fritters, chili-crusted calamari, hot and sour hot pot soup, sweet basil vegetables or green curry chicken. The dinner menu includes pad see ew, Chiang Mai-style pork stew and short ribs with Massaman curry.

____________

HARU, 5210 Longley Lane, 775-507-7355

Haru means "spring" or "springtime" in Japanese. A painted cherry blossom tree in bloom, a symbol of Japan, frames the entrance to the restaurant, whose Longley Lane neighbors include Great Full Gardens and Butter & Salt.

Blond wood tables and shoji screens populate the dining room. The menu ranges from build-your-own ramen with various stocks, flavor foundations and toppings to yakitori and kushiyaki skewers issuing from the grill to small plates like Japanese fried chicken.

____________

MAGGIE'S BREAKFAST & LUNCH, 271 Wonder St., 775-507-7006

Maggie's set up shop in the former (and short-lived) Baja Bakery & Deli on Wonder Street, in the Wells Avenue Neighborhood Conservation District. The dining room is sunny and cozy.

For breakfast, the kitchen sends out omelets (with meat choices that include chorizo), sandwiches like an El Caliente with jalapeño, Maggie's pancakes, a burrito with choice of meat and huevos Mexicana.

At lunch, think a tuna avocado salad, vegetarian or chipotle chicken wraps, or sandwiches like a chicken bacon club, a B.L.T. or a Philly-style steak with grilled onions, provolone and Swiss.

____________

____________Fp

MINDFUL CUPCAKES, 6300 Mae Anne Ave., 775-360-6555

Mindful Cupcakes started out supplying to local retailers its signature cupcakes that are free from gluten, grains, dairy, soy and refined sugar. Now, there's a Mindful shop in the same Northwest Reno center that also includes Peg's Glorified Ham n Eggs.

The store sells chocolate, cinnamon and vanilla cupcakes individually or in four-packs; cinnamon and pumpkin spice muffins (also free from gluten, etc.); sandwiches from Full Belly Deli; coffee from the Hub; and cupcake, sandwich and beverage combo lunches.

____________

MONACIELLO, 190 California Ave., 775-507-7540

Where pizza once flourished it flourishes again. Monaciello (tagline: The Pizza & Pasta Place) resides in the old Blue Moon Pizza on California Avenue. Jacob Gordon, who once had the Tuscan Tomato in the Summit, is chef-owner.

The website touts the restaurant's housemade ingredients: sauces, pastas, pizza dough, sausage.

The menu features dishes like spicy prawn Benedict for breakfast, a pork belly with habanero jelly appetizer, salads, a lamb leg sandwich, burgers, a tilapia small plate, smoked salmon spätzle, and more than a dozen house pizzas (plus build-your-own).

____________

RASPADOS LA PERLA JALISCO, 469 E. Plumb Lane, 775-379-1849

Raspado means "scraped" in Spanish, and that action is incorporated into another meaning of the word: "snow cone" or "shave ice." Raspados La Perla lies across the parking lot from Marisco's El Pescador on East Plumb Lane.

Besides shave ice, Raspados La Perla offers licuados (smoothies), milkshakes, fruit cups with various flavor additions, ice cream, and snacks like mango with chile powder and Mexican grilled corn.

____________

RUE BOURBON, 1401 S. Virginia St., 775-384-6526

Rue Bourbon occupies what used to be the second floor of Morgan's Lobster Shack in Midtown Reno. The owners of Rue Bourbon broke through to an adjacent unused space, more than doubling the size of the footprint.

A mural depicting the restaurant's namesake enlivens the dining room and bar, and original art, sourced from the owners' trips to New Orleans, fills the restaurant. Rue Bourbon also is wired for remote work and presentations.

The menu features a small selection of New Orleans standards like beignets, po' boys, muffulettas and sazerac cocktails. There's also a big parking lot out back (a huge rarity in Midtown). Look for a longer profile of Rue Bourbon on RGJ.com in the weeks ahead.

____________

SABOR LATIN CUISINE, 585 E. Moana Lane, 775-433-1308

Sabor is the latest Latino restaurant to open in its East Moana Lane center, joining Yesenia Pupuseria y Taqueria next door and Mendoza's Bar & Grill several doors down. El Tumi Peruvian Restaurant previously occupied the Sabor premises.

Sabor's menu mingles dishes from across the Latin world. There are carne asada tacos and chile verde from Mexico, lomo saltado and jalea seafood platters from Peru, and Argentinean-style steak. Beverages include horchata and cebada toasted barley drink.

____________

WHISPERING VINE WINE CO., 772 S. Virginia St.

Whispering Vine, celebrating its 20th anniversary in 2018, opened its fourth location in October, this time in the Sticks development in Midtown Reno. The latest Whispering Vine debuted in a glass-walled space that encompasses 2,300 square feet.

The new shop features a capacious central bar, on-premise and retail wine and spirits, barrel programs with local distilleries and the first-ever whiskey bottled for the store, courtesy of Tuthilltown Spirits Distillery in Upstate New York.

search_result.title: Tennis greats celebrate 40 years of World TeamTennis
search_result.text:
Denise Goolsby

The Desert Sun

Mylan World TeamTennis last week celebrated its 40th anniversary with a tennis star-studded reception that featured a conversation with WTT co-founder Billie Jean King.

Monday's event was held during the BNP Paribas Open at Indian Wells Tennis Garden. Coincidentally, the tournament also is celebrating its 40th anniversary season.

The mid-1970s — when these ambitious ventures were launched — proved to be a pivotal time in the world of professional tennis. It was during these barnstorming years when pioneers like King worked fiercely and tirelessly to create a solid foundation for the game — the colorful, powerful, fast-paced variety we enjoy today.

The anniversary event, held in the gorgeously-appointed hospitality tent located near Stadium 1, drew a large crowd of former and current WTT players.

Huge photo banners of players through the years hung on the walls of the venue. Old WTT uniforms, some created by world famous designer Ted Tinling, were on display near a beautiful white sheet cake emblazoned with the Mylan World TeamTennis logo.

In October 2012, Mylan, a generics and specialty pharmaceutical company, signed a three-year agreement with World TeamTennis to serve as title sponsor of WTT.

World TeamTennis, a groundbreaking co-ed professional league launched in 1974, featured quirky, multicolored tennis courts that added some pop to a sport that could sometimes be considered staid — think all-white tennis outfits — back in the day.

Looking back, WTT was a trendsetter, as you now see blue surfaces. used for major tournaments. The BNP Paribas Open takes it a step further with purple courts.

WTT Commissioner Ilana Kloss kicked off Monday's program with a video of WTT highlights throughout the years.

Tennis commentator Mary Carillo — witty, insightful and always quick with a playful, verbal jab — moderated a panel discussion between King and former professional and WTT players Chris Evert, Roy Emerson, Lindsay Davenport and Andy Roddick.

In an intimate setting — panelists lounging comfortably on orange suede coaches — the group talked about the history of the league and how the experience of playing on competitive co-ed professional teams made an impact on their careers.

The group sat in front of a backdrop featuring the Mylan WTT logo and the league's motto: Game Changers and Ground Breakers.

"I played a couple of seasons of World TeamTennis before I ever played Davis Cup matches," Roddick said. "It was a great experience for me as far as learning how to work inside the framework of a team."

Larry King, Billie Jean King's former husband who helped launch World TeamTennis, talked to The Desert Sun about the sport's early popularity.

"When World TeamTennis started in the 1974 season, the first five seasons we had five million spectators," he said. "It was the biggest exhibition of tennis in the United States, with our 20 teams playing. In ' 74, '75 and '76, World TeamTennis players won all of the Wimbledon and Forest Hills (U.S. Open) events.

"They say it's a development tool because it sharpened the players' tools for the tournaments. But it was a great event for the spectators, too."

Billie Jean King, Evert, Emerson, Rosie Casals and Jimmy Connors were among the first players to compete in the inaugural year.

King played for the Philadelphia Freedoms in 1974, and she was the inspiration behind Elton John's "Philadelphia Freedom," which became the team's theme song. She also was named the league's first MVP.

As the coach of the Philadelphia Freedoms, Billie Jean King became the first female coach of a sports team featuring male athletes.

Switching teams, in 1975, King led the New York Sets to the first of her league championships in 1976, the year Martina Navratilova made her debut in WTT, joining the Cleveland Nets.

Evert became the first WTT player to win back-to-back MVP awards, taking home the honors in 1977 and '78.

After a short hiatus, the league retooled itself for a comeback in 1981.

In 1982, I got my first real taste of World TeamTennis when I attended a Los Angeles Strings match at the Forum.

It's also where I first met the tennis legend herself.

During a break in the action, I joined small a crowd courtside where King was kind enough to autograph her book, "Billie Jean," for this wide-eyed tennis fan.

King has been a dynamic force in tennis since the early 1960s. She's won 39 Grand Slam titles, but her contributions to the game — and to society — extend far beyond the court.

Within a two-year span alone, from 1973 to 1974, King beat Bobby Riggs in the Battle of the Sexes — a monumental moment that forever changed the landscape of women's sports and empowered female athletes — and founded the Women's Tennis Association, Women's Sports Foundation and Women's Sports Magazine.

She was recently included in CNN's list of seven women "who changed the world," along with the likes of Harriet Beecher Stowe (author and anti-slavery campaigner), Jewish schoolgirl Anne Frank (whose diary recalled her life under German occupation) and Emmeline Pankhurst (led women's right to vote movement).

The champion of women's sports and equality for all enthusiastically shared her appreciation for Monday's celebration.

"I'm so excited because we're bringing so many people together from different generations — we're not only bringing players, but we're bringing owners, staff, people who worked through the years," King said.

"I'm very thankful and blessed that we're 40 years old and that these people are showing up tonight to celebrate."

Denise Goolsby is The Desert Sun's columnist for history and profiles. She can be reached at Denise.Goolsby@DesertSun.com and on Twitter @DeniseGoolsby

search_result.title: Fall things to do in NJ during COVID: Your guide to fall arts and events
search_result.text:
Orchestras, art galleries, plays, dance performances, comedy shows — we've missed you.

It's been a long summer without arts programming, as galleries shuttered and shows were canceled because of COVID-19. But now, museums and outdoor performance venues are slowly reopening.

Here are some of the art events you can attend — in person and virtually — this autumn.

Ballet

Dracula: The Atlantic City Ballet will present “Dracula”, based on Bram Stoker’s 1897 classic gothic horror story. Choreographer Phyllis Papa’s Dracula “mixes romance and passion with horror and pain.” The show is scheduled for Oct. 24 at 7 p.m. at Circus Maximus Theater at Caesars. Tickets are $20-45. 609-348-4411; caesars.com/caesars-ac/shows.

Jersey City Ballet, Jersey City The Jersey City Ballet has rehearsed over Zoom for its November show, a recital made up of excerpts from classical ballets. Follow Jersey City Ballet on social media or go to its website for more information about the performance. Nov. 21 (time TBA), Roy Irving Theatre at St. Peter’s University, 2641 John F. Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City. Price TBD. 551-655-9875; jerseycityballet.org

Shore holiday: The Atlantic City Ballet presents “It’s a shore holiday” on Nov. 21 at 7 p.m. to help you get into the holiday spirit. They call it a “radio city-esque” review, which features contemporary and classical dance set to holiday tunes. Singers and a live band transport viewers to a “holiday winter wonderland.” Tickets are $45-50. ticketmaster.com

Comedy

Vic DiBitetto: Need comic relief? Head to the Vic DiBitetto set – a drive-in comedy show at Westfield Garden State Plaza, hosted by bergenPAC. DiBitetto is known for ranting about Justin Bieber and Kanye West on YouTube, hosting Gotham Comedy Live on AXS TV and launching his television talk show "The Vic DiBitettos Show. '' 7 p.m. Oct. 9 Garden State Plaza parking lot, 1 Garden State Plaza, Paramus $229 (for a VIP 1 ticket, closest to the stage), $159 (VIP 2, close to the stage), $99 (general admission for the whole car), $79 (general admission for a car with only two people in it) 201-227-1030; bergenpac.org

Concerts

American Symphony Orchestra’s Quartet, Morristown A string quartet from the American Symphony Orchestra will perform works by Black composers, outside on the grounds of the Morris Museum of Art. The quartet includes concertmaster Cyrus Beroukhim, violinist Phillip Payton, principal viola William Frampton and cellist Alberto Parrini. Expect to hear traditional gospel and folk songs, arranged by Florence Price, the first Black woman to have one of her works performed by a major orchestra. Bring your own chairs 6 p.m. Oct. 17 (doors open at 4:30 p.m.) Morris Museum of Art, 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown $50 for an 8-foot-by-8-foot block that can fit two people. 973-971-3706; morrismuseum.org

"A Kind of September: An Evening with Kate Baldwin" is a benefit concert scheduled for Sept. 25 and Oct 2 at 7:30 p.m., presented by the Shakespeare Theatre of NJ. It's one of three productions booked for the theater's Back Yard Stage at 3 Vreeland Road, Florham Park. Others include "Shaw! Shaw! Shaw!" three one-act plays by George Bernard Shaw ("Village Wooing," "Passion, Poison, and Petrifaction" and "Overruled"), running Oct. 14 to 25 and "Something Wicked This Way Comes," an annual attraction billed as a "family-friendly three-night Halloween event" (it will feature seasonal readings by actors from a variety of sources) at 7 p.m.Oct. 29 to 31. shakespearenj.org

Cape May Music Festival: Bay Atlantic Symphony music director Jed Gaylin, and New York Chamber Ensemble artistic director Eliot Bailen, who are long time friends, will present four short performances for classical music lovers to enjoy virtually as part of the 2020 Cape May Music Festival Series. The schedule features: “Bounce & Ballads,” 5:30 p.m. Sept. 17; “In the Moment,” 5:30 p.m. Sept. 22 and “Serenades & Dreams,” 5:30 p.m. Oct. 1. After each free concert, the pair will be live on Zoom to field questions. Donations welcome. bayatlanticsymphony.org or capemaymac.org

“Carnival of the Animals.” The classic Saint Saens salute to our furry and feathered friends, a children’s favorite, is being given a special online presentation by the New Jersey Symphony. Different pieces in the suite will be hosted by different members of the symphony: Violinist David Blinn, principal bass Alexander Bickard, principal flute Bart Feller, assistant principal cello Na-Young Baek. Children’s drawings, online, add a whole other layer of charm. njsymphony.org/musicians-music/njso-at-home/learn/carnival-animals-video-series

Cedric the Entertainer, Union County Performing Arts Center, Rahway The Union County Performing Arts Center will present Cedric the Entertainer on Dec. 12 at 8 p.m. Cedric’s film work spans genres from the comedic, highlighted by his memorable performances in the hit “Barbershop” franchise, to the dramatic with Oscar-nominated drama “First Reformed.” His signature baritone voice has been heard in animated hits such as Disney’s “Madagascar” and “Planes” franchises, “Ice Age 2” and “Dr. Dolittle 2” among others. Union County Performing Arts Center at 1601 Irving St, Rahway; Dec. 12 at 8 p.m.; $99; ucpac.org/event/20600d9a47ad7eb9c632aad30dcaa217

Concerts in the Garden at the Blu Grotto: Max Weinberg's Jukebox, 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Sept. 24 and Friday, Sept. 25, $59 to $79. Nate Bargatze, 7 and 9:30 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 26, $29 to $59. Bill Burr, 7 and 9:30 p.m. Wednesday, Sept. 30, Sold out. The Lone Bellow, 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 1, $39 to $59. Theo Von, 7 and 9:30 p.m., Saturday, Oct. 3, $29 to $69. Wynton Marsalis, 2 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 4, $59 to $99. Imagine with Marc Ribler and Friends John Lennon tribute , 7:30 p.m. Friday, Oct. 9, $39 to $55.50. Tusk, 7:30 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 10, $35 to $49.50. Co-Dependent Tour with Whitney Cummings and Taylor Tomlinson, 7 and 9:30 p.m. Sunday, Oct 18, $29 to $59. 200 Port Au Peck Ave., Oceanport. thebasie.org/garden or blugrottonj.com.

Count Basie Center for the Arts: The Capitol Steps, 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 8, $19 to $39. Bobby Bandiera: Runnin’ Down A Dream Tom Petty tribute, 7:30 p.m. Friday, Oct. 30, $19 to $39. Sergio Mendes, 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 5, $35 to $79. Erth's Dinosaur Zoo Live, 1 and 4 p.m. Sunday, Nov. 8, $25 to $39. Art Garfunkel: In Close-Up, 8 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 19, $35 to $89. Midtown Men: Holiday Hits, 8 p.m. Thursday, Dec. 17, $29 to $79. Shows subject to change. 99 Monmouth St., Red Bank. (732) 842-9000; thebasie.org

Judy Collins: Grammy-winning singer Judy Collins will croon at bergenPAC’s summer drive-in series, held in the Westfield Garden State Plaza parking lot in Paramus. The singer is known for her songs “Someday Soon,” “Chelsea Morning” and her renditions of “Amazing Grace” and “Send in the Clowns." When you arrive, you'll be directed to a parking space from which you'll watch the show. The drive-in features LED screens and food trucks. Gates open two hours before the show. 7 p.m. Sept. 26, Garden State Plaza parking lot, 1 Garden State Plaza, Paramus. $250 (for a VIP 1 ticket, closest to the stage), $179 (VIP 2, close to the stage), $129 (general admission for the whole car), $99 (general admission for a car with only two people in it). 201-227-1030; bergenpac.org

Mayo Performing Arts Center: 100 South St., Morristown. The Nerds, 6 and 8:30 p.m. Friday, Oct. 16. Cover band. $35 to $50; The 8:30 pm show will be available for livestream for $20. Anthony Krizan and Friends, 8 p.m. Friday, Nov. 13. Krizan calls his music "blues infused rock & roll with soulful swampy under tones." $35 to $50. Livestream available for $20. mayoarts.org.

New Jersey Symphony Orchestra: NJSO Virtual 20–21 launches with an at-home performance of the finale of Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony. The video premieres on Oct. 29 on the NJSO’s YouTube and social channels and at njsymphony.org. The NJSO joins forces with Newark-based opera company Trilogy for a video presentation of selections from Michael Raphael’s Emmett Till oratorio at 8 p.m. Nov. 10. Join community leaders and Trilogy Artistic Director Kevin Maynor for an evening of conversation about the impact of Till’s murder and the way that art and music help tell important stories, followed by an exclusive premiere of the project. The NJSO also will present virtual concerts that will be streamed online for free. The first program, which premieres at 7:30 p.m. Nov. 19, features the world premiere of "i am a white person who _____ Black people," a new NJSO commission by composer Daniel Bernard Roumain. All virtual concerts air on the NJSO’s YouTube and social media channels. For a full list of scheduled NJSO Virtual 20–21 programs, visit www.njsymphony.org/virtual.

Outdoor Concerts Somerville: Somerville’s outdoor concert series continues on Division Street until Oct. 24. Audience members are asked to sit six feet away from other groups and wear masks. Bring your own lawn chairs and blankets for the performances, as follows: Bryan Hansen Band on Sept. 19, The Outcrops on Sept. 26, John Busse on Oct. 3, Tyrone Stackhouse on Oct. 10, Mike Holland (an Elvis impersonator) on Oct. 17, and The Paul Nagy Project on Oct. 24. 6 to 9 p.m. on select dates. Division Street. Free. downtownsomerville.com

Rio Clemente & Regan Ryzuk at the Watchung Arts Center, Watchung: Rio Clemente, with special guest pianist-composer Regan Ryzuk, will present a concert on Oct. 24 from 8-9:30 p.m. at the Watchung Arts Center in Watchung. Clemente has recorded for well-known labels and has published 20 CDs under his own label. He has also co-written selections ranging from gospel to Latin, including orchestral arrangements. Tickets cost $25 at the door or $20 in advance. Watchung Arts Center at 18 Stirling Road, Watchung; Oct. 24 at 8 p.m.; $20-$25; watchungarts.org/event/rio-clemente-jazz-in-the-gallery-march-14-2020/?instance_id=585

Scottish Rite Porch Concert Series: On Sept. 25 at 7 p.m., Collingswood’s Birdie Busch will appear on the porch of the Mansion at the Scottish Rite with John Falco’s Drytown and opening band Wayside Shakeup. Bring your own lawn chair. There is plenty of room to safely social distance and masks are required when not seated. Grounds open at 6:15 pm. Bar will be open for alcohol sales. 313 White Horse Pike in Collingwood. Event Brite at eventbrite.com/e/118043179327 or email mbaldwin@collingswoodarts.com to reserve a space. Seating is limited. Admission is $15. Hotsy Totsy appears on the proch on Oct. 2 at 7 p.m. The Collingswood based indie-pop trio broke onto the Philly music scene in early 2014. $15. Grounds open at 6:15 pm. Bring your own lawn chair, snacks, soft drinks. Admission at eventbrite.com/e/119620424911

Exhibits

Dissonance exhibition: The Morris Museum of Art’s current exhibition “Dissonance” is organized into six categories: performance, abstraction, figural realism, points of view, object-based and photography. The 59 works by 39 artists in this display attempt to embody dissonance, defined by the museum as “discord, tension, instability and conflict." Tickets must be bought in advance; timed entry only is available to help control crowds. Through Feb. 21, Morris Museum of Art, 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. Price: $12 for adults, $8 for seniors, students and children aged 3 to 17, free for under 3, 973-971-3706; morrismuseum.org

Federico Uribe: Animalia exhibit, Montclair: The Montclair Museum of Art has reopened, along with its Federico Uribe: Animalia exhibit. Uribe is known for creating mixed media paintings and sculptures of colorful landscapes and animals. Uribe takes bric-a-brac like colored pencils, shoelaces and plastic waste to create his pieces -- representative of his belief that war and destruction can be transformed into peace and beauty. There are more than 60 pieces on display at the exhibit, including a few made specifically for the show. Some things to know: You must purchase your ticket ahead of time online. Contactless check-in and temperature checks will take place when you arrive, and masks are required at all times. Through Jan. 3, Montclair Art Museum, 3 S. Mountain Ave., Montclair. $14 for adults, $12 for students and seniors, free for under 12 973-746-5555; montclairartmuseum.org

"From The Ground Up" art exhibition, Hunterdon Art Museum, Clinton The Hunterdon Art Museum will present “From The Ground Up,” the first-ever exhibition examining Peters Valley School of Craft 50-year history and key moments that have defined the institution. It will combine historical ephemera with works in fiber, jewelry, ceramics, wood, photography, and metal by artists involved at Peters Valley, as well as those from on-site artist residencies. The exhibit will be available at the museum, both live and virtually, from Oct. 4 through Jan. 10. Hunterdon Art Museum at 7 Lower Center St, Clinton; Oct. 4-Jan. 10; $7 admission; hunterdonartmuseum.org/from-the-ground-up-peters-valley-school-of-craft/

The Gallery Space: "In Search of Superheroes," featuring art that focus on popular superheroes, Nov. 8 to Dec. 6, 1670 Irving St., Rahway. Opens on Sunday, Nov. 8, from 1 to 4 pm. Open from 1 to 4 p.m. Mondays through Fridays. Closing reception is from 1 to 4 p.m. Sunday, Dec. 6. Free. Info: Lawrence Cappiello at 732-827-2210 or lcappiello@cityofrahway.com.

Grounds for Sculpture: 42-acre park scattered with nearly 300 massive, contemporary sculptures – an ideal place to see something different during quarantine. Special events will take place throughout autumn, including: Garden Stories (a virtual story telling hour followed by a self-guided visit to the garden, $5 for kids, $20 for adults) on Oct. 4; Mind, Body and Balance (a workshop on how to practice mindfulness and yoga, $20) on Oct. 10; Botanical Drawing (a six-week course on how to illustrate nature, $140) on Oct. 10, 17, 24, 31 and Nov. 7 and 14; and Nature Journaling for Beginners (a workshop on how to journal your nature experience, $40) on Oct. 14. groundsforsculpture.org/events Hours are 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Mondays and Thursdays; 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. Friday through Sunday; and closed Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Tickets are $18 for adults; $15 for seniors 65 and up, as well as active military or veterans and healthcare workers; $10 for students ages 6 to 17 with an ID; free for under 5. 80 Sculptors Way, Hamilton Township; 609-586-0616; groundsforscupture.org

Juried exhibition: Medford Arts Center has its 2020 Fall Fine Art Juried Exhibition online (all media) from Sept. 11 through Oct. 8. Its 2020 Great Outdoors Juried Exhibition online, including landscapes, seascapes and other outdoor scenes and all media is Oct. 9 through Nov. 12 and its Veteran’s Art Juried Exhibition all media is Nov. 6 through Dec. 7. medfordarts.com

Metlar-Bodine House Museum: Piscataway’s 354-year-old story told in a docent-led tour. See why and how America’s tradition of celebrating July 4 began in Piscataway in 1778. View a map display of the museum’s theme “From Indian Trail to Interstate” – a journey through time. Socially distant tours and the Dutch Door Gift Shop are open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Thursdays from Nov. 19 to Dec. 17, on Saturdays from noon to 5 p.m. Dec. 5, 12 and 19, and from noon to 5 p.m. Sunday, Dec. 13. Group tours of four must schedule in advance. $5, free for children under 5. Pay at the door (no credit cards accepted). Masks required before entering the museum and must be worn during visit. The museum cannot supply masks. Hand sanitizer available at admission desk and in the gift shop. INFO: 732-463-8363 or www.metlarbodinehousemuseum.org/home

Monmouth Museum: Juried Art Exhibition and Member Miniatures, Nov. 13 to Jan. 3, 2021. Opening reception is 3 to 6 p.m. Nov. 14. Reserve your space at eventbrite.com/e/125176537393. Free. The museum, 765 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, is open by appointment from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through Fridays. Info: cesposito@monmouthmuseum.org or 732-224-1988 or monmouthmuseum.org.

“Mood Books: The Children’s Stories of Alvin Tresselt and Roger Duvoisin” art exhibition, Zimmerli Art Museum, New Brunswick. The Zimmerli Art Museum, located on the Rutgers University-New Brunswick campus, is presenting “Mood Books: The Children’s Stories of Alvin Tresselt and Roger Duvoisin” through Dec. 30. The art exhibition, which is drawn entirely from the museum’s permanent collection, features illustrations from four of the authors’ books to celebrate the union of Tresselt’s storytelling and Duvoisin’s artwork. Zimmerli Art Museum, 71 Hamilton St, New Brunswick; through Dec. 30; free; zimmerlimuseum.rutgers.edu/duvoisin-gallery/mood-books-children%E2%80%99s-stories-alvin-tresselt-and-roger-duvoisin#.X1_JqchKg2x

Outdoor art gallery: “The Gallery in the Park” is featured at Washington Lake Park at 626 Hurffville-Cross Keys Road, Sewell. The Sustainable Washington Township Creative Team is presenting its first exhibit at the outdoor gallery and the theme, “eARTh without ART is just eh,” celebrates the 50th anniversary of the first Earth Day and will be on display until October. The project is supported in part by the South Jersey Cultural Alliance and OceanFirst Bank. getshotbybrian.com/wp-content.

Perkins juried exhibition: Perkins Center for the Arts will hold is 2020 Fall Juried Exhibition Oct. 10 to Nov. 22. Gallery hours are Thursday and Friday 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. and Saturday and Sunday 1 p.m. to 4 p.m. Opening reception is Oct. 10 from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. (free and open to the public). Juror Henry Bermudez currently teaches art at the Career Academy Developing Institute (CADI) and at Fleisher Art Memorial. He is co-director of HouseGallery1816 in Fishtown and is the recipient of a Peter Benoliel Fellowship from CFEVA in Philadelphia. perkinsarts.org

Tuckerton Borough Fine Arts Gallery: Pine Shores Art Association exhibit featuring 50 framed paintings and drawings by 20 artists, on display in the center hall and courtroom, with original works by Ed Renner featured in the conference room.

Tuckerton Borough Fine Arts Gallery is located in the municipal building at 420 E. Main St. Public viewing hours are weekdays from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. throughout November and December, except when the building is closed for holidays or other special exceptions. The art is for sale. Info: Contact exhibit curator Nancy Lang at nancylang07@gmail.com or www.pineshoresartassociation.org.

Wedding Dresses: The Shrewsbury Historical Society and Research Center, 419 Sycamore Ave., is featuring a curated collection of wedding fashions from the Victorian and Edwardian eras to the early 20th century to current fashions. The exhibit, running Oct. 3 to Nov. 28, will be open from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Thursdays and Saturdays, and by appointment by emailing ShrewsburyHistoricalSociety@gmail.com. Visitors are asked to follow COVID-19 protocols.

Wheaton conversations: Artists Wendel White, a Newark native, and Glynnis Reed lead this conversation on Sept. 24 at 6 p.m., virtually. The accomplished artists discuss “their creative process, traditions of African American art and photography, and their approaches to interweaving identity with nature and place.” Wheaton conversations is a new virtual series that highlights artists with ties to Wheaton Arts and Cultural Center in Millville. Go to: us/webinar/register

Festivals

Collingswood Book Festival: 18th annual event is live and virtual on the first week of October with interactive poetry workshops and readings, author presentations, a panel discussion about diversity, children's poetry contest, and opportunities for young people to connect with authors. Look for a virtual Drag Queen Story Hour, a diversity panel discussing children's books that highlight race, gender, sexual orientation and special needs; and a noontime poetry write-in, in addition to readings and author talks online.

On Sunday, Oct. 4, the festival will host a free outdoors socially distant poetry reading at the Scottish Rite Theatre complex on White Horse Pike, featuring Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Gregory Pardlo. Keep up with the latest announcements at collingswoodbookfestival.com/ or on Facebook at facebook.com/Collsbook

Dunellen HarvestFest, Dunellen The eighth annual Dunellen HarvestFest is coming to Dunellen’s Washington Park on Oct. 11 from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. with local artists and crafters, a pumpkin decorating contest, activities for kids, food, music and more. Booths will be spaced out to allow for social distancing. Washington Park at N. Washington Ave., Dunellen; Oct. 11 from 11 a.m.-4 p.m.; free. sites.google.com/a/dunellenborough.com/dunellenharvestfest/

Fantasy Island Amusement Park: between 7th and 8th streets, Beach Haven. Arcade open Fridays through Saturdays in September, Saturdays and Sundays through the end of the year. Rides open weekends through Oct. 11. Unlimited rides for $25 per rider, every Saturday and Sunday through Oct. 10. Fall Fireworks Spectacular is 8 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 10. 2nd annual Halloween Fun Fest is noon to 4 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 11. There will be trick-or-treating, a pumpkin patch, a costume contest and more. In order to operate safely this season, Fantasy Island added new Safe Play guidelines earlier this year for guests and team members to follow. These guidelines will remain in effect during the fall season and can be found at fantasyislandlbi.com/covid-19/.

Greek Agora Festival: Oct. 8 to 11, St. Thomas Greek Orthodox Church in Cherry Hill and is being limited to just food and to drive-thru and pickup with several ways to order. There won’t be music, dancing, craft vendors or bar and seating this year. Many favorites will still be available on a limited menu at the festival, often touted as the largest food and wine event in the Delaware Valley. greekagorafestival.com/

St. Padre Pio Festival: The St. Padre Pio Parish hosts its annual St. Padre Pio Festival noon to 6 p.m. Sept. 27 at St. Padre Pio Parish, 4680 Dante Ave., Vineland. A Mass and procession will be held at 11 a.m., followed by an Italian-language Mass at 2 p.m. The festival features Italian favorites including sausage & peppers, porchetta, and pasta platters. Attendees are asked to comply with COVID safeguards, including face makes and social distancing. Advanced ordering for takeout is recommended. 856-691-7526; pppnj.org.

Somerville Street Fair & Craft Show, Somerville A street fair and craft show will be held in downtown Somerville on Oct. 4 from 11 a.m.-5 p.m. in the borough. It will include artists, crafters and vendors selling their wares, as well as food, rides, live music, a petting zoo, martial arts exhibitions and more. Free admission for spectators. Sunday, Oct. 4 11 a.m.-5 p.m.; free; downtown Somerville; eventbrite.com/e/somerville-street-fair-craft-show-tickets-87073448027

Winefest NJ 2020: Valenzano Family Winery in Shamong will host "New Jersey’s most attended and longest continuously running wine and music" event on September 19 and 20, from 12 to 5 p.m. It will be held at Valenzano Winery, 1090 Route 206, Shamong. valenzanowine.com; 609-268-6731, ext. 303 for information.

Virtual Tasting: William Heritage Winery in Mullica Hill will host a virtual wine tasting on Sept. 24 at 6:30 p.m. The cost is $80. Participants can taste along with the winemaking crew on Instagram LIVE. The wine box, which must be purchased in advance, includes 2018 Merlot 2018 Syrah 2018 Chambourcin, suggested cheese & chocolate pairing cards, wine evaluation sheets. heritagewinenj.com/events/

Film

Films in the Garden. "Home," a 2015 animated film about an intergalactic friendship, featuring the voices of Jim Parsons and Rihanna. 7 p.m. Oct. 15. "Gramercy", a 22-minute short about a troubled young man who returns to his Jersey hometown, and "Dark City Beneath The Beat," a 65-minute musical documentary about Baltimore club music. 7 p.m. Oct. 22. In the garden adjacent to Newark Museum of Art, 49 Washington St., Newark. newarkmuseumart.org/

“Heart of Camden”: Documentary about Monsignor Michael Doyle and his life and work in Camden’s Waterfront South neighborhood, is moving outdoors. Originally scheduled to be screened at South Camden Theatre Company in mid-March, the film’s premiere will become a drive-in movie event on Oct. 9 with social distancing, masking and other safety protocols observed. The screening will be at 7 p.m. at Cooper Poynt Waterfront Park in Camden. Tickets are $30 per person and benefit the housing nonprofit Heart of Camden. Advance tickets required. tinyurl.com/y3s7phez to reserve tickets.

The Rocky Horror Picture Show, 8 p.m. Friday, Oct. 30, Mayo Performing Arts Center, 100 South St., Morristown. $20, includes goodie bag. mayoarts.org.

Theater

Algonquin Theatre: Jekyll & Hyde, Oct. 16 through Oct. 25, Algonquin Theatre, 60 Abe Voorhees Dr, Manasquan. www.algonquinarts.org. The Broadway hit will bring out the beast in you. Subject to change. Elf, Nov. 28 through Dec. 13, Algonquin Theatre, 60 Abe Voorhees Dr, Manasquan. www.algonquinarts.org. Get into the season spirit with this tale of an abnormally large elf. Subject to change. calgonquinarts.org

Dracula, The Radio Play, Oct. 29 to 31, www.thetheaterproject.org. The Theater Project is offering some comfort food on the Zoom platform: "Dracula, The Radio Play," as it might have been performed in the Lux Radio Theater in 1932. The show will be performed live on Zoom at 7:30 p.m. Thursday and Friday, and streamed at 2 and 9 p.m. Saturday on Halloween. The company had relocated to Union Township just before theaters were shuttered due to Covid-19. Suggested donation is $15, www.thetheaterproject.org.

'Ghost Hunt: The Hall-Mills Double Homicide' game, podcast and production, New Brunswick "THOU SHALT NOT," a stage play based on the infamous, unsolved Hall-Mills murders which took place in Somerset County nearly a century ago, was set to premiere this spring in New York City. Although COVID-19 made that impossible, the directors have created 'Ghost Hunt: The Hall-Mills Double Homicide,' a game which uses the free gaming app Geocaching in which audiences can track, hunt, and discover hidden caches at locations tied to Hall-Mills murders in New Brunswick, Manhattan, Brooklyn, Venice, Italy, Virginia, and Texas. Although the tangible experience is only available in said locations, one can still explore and listen from the comfort of their own homes through audio material on the website. Download Geocaching app and visit thinkeryandverse.org for Ghost Hunt instructions and podcast. Free donations accepted.

'The Lodger, Sabotage and The 39 Steps, Vintage Hitchcock: A Live Radio Play,' Kearny The West Hudson Arts and Theater Company will perform a “live radio play” inspired by the work of Alfred Hitchcock. “The Lodger, Sabotage and The 39 Steps, Vintage Hitchcock: A Live Radio Play” tells three of Hitchcock’s stories – one about a train chase, another about a stalking serial kittler and the third about a tragic explosion. The show is set in a 1940s radio station and the actors perform as if reading a radio broadcast, complete with old-school commercials. Dusk on Oct. 24 Outside in Arlington Depot Park, Kearny TBA 201-467-8624; whatco.org

More:NJ festivals offer virtual fun this fall

Tevye Served Raw. Before there was “Fiddler on the Roof,” there were a bunch of comic stories by Yiddish writer Sholem Aleichem, about a poor Jewish dairyman and his highly marriageable daughters. Centenary Stage Company in Hackettstown is going back to basics, October 22 through October 25, when their Fringe Festival presents “Tevye Served Raw,” billed as a deeper, more authentic presentation of the stories that leaves in a lot of what “Fiddler” took out. At the Sitnik Theatre of the Lackland Performing Arts Center on the campus of Centenary University, 715 Grand Ave., Hackettstown. centenarystageco.org

Virtual events

A Conversation with Howardena Pindell. The groundbreaking artist and Museum of Modern Art art curator, whose own work deals with issues of war, genocide, sexism, and xenophobia, can be seen online in conversation with Mitra Abbaspour on 5:30 p.m. Friday, September 25, 2020, courtesy of the Princeton Museum of Art, which remains closed for the time being. artmuseum.princeton.edu

"Angela Davis—Seize the Time." The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli art museum at Rutgers New Brunswick is dark for the time being. But a number of exhibitions have migrated online, and other streaming programs are being offered for adults and children as well. "Angela Davis—Seize the Time", a virtual book launch, will begin 5:30 p.m. Oct. 1. "Art Before/After Hours," featuring two live streams, as well as recorded content, will run twice, from 9 to 10 a.m. or 7 to 8 p.m. Oct. 6. Other programs are also scheduled for September and October. Visit zimmerlimuseum.rutgers.edu

Arcadia Trio live-streamed concert: Members of the Arcadian Trio will perform in concert on October 18 at 7:30 p.m. for the West Jersey Chamber Music Society (WJCMS) in A Lively Conversation: Beethoven, Ravel, and de Falla, a free livestream, online-only event. The first such broadcast for WJCMS, it presents works by Beethoven, Ravel, and de Falla alongside introductory commentary. The live video broadcast will be available at concert time at WJCMS.org. Pianist Diane Goldsmith and cellist Vivian Barton Dozor, members of the Arcadian Trio, are joined by narrator Ivan Woods.

Brookside Cabaret Series. Come to the cabaret! A cabaret series and a program of Wednesday rock concerts will keep things lively at The Paper Mill Playhouse, the iconic regional theater in Millburn. Kathryn Allison (October 1–3); Kelli Rabke, joined by guitarist Sean Harkness and pianist John Fischer (October 8–10); Elizabeth Ward Land’s tribute to Linda Ronstadt, with Matt Castle (October 15–17); and Susan Speidel and Joe Regan (October 22–24), will be featured at the Brookside Cabaret series at the F.M. Kirby Carriage House Restaurant, 6:30 p.m. Thursday, Friday, and Saturday evenings. "Rocktober Wednesdays" at the Carriage House, 6:30 p.m. (weather permitting) will feature local bands This Old Engine (September 30), Spare Tire Band (October 7), Soular Bone (October 14), and the Squeaky Wheels (October 21). papermill.org

Brookdale Student Photography Exhibit: 6 to 8 p.m. Friday, Sept. 25, Oyster Point Hotel, 146 Bodman Place, Red Bank. Free. To augment the FOCI photography exhibit, curator Ellen Martin and Oyster Point V.P. Kevin Barry invited the students of Brookdale Community College's Darkroom I and Darkroom II classes to exhibit their work. It will take place on the second floor of the hotel. In order to respect social distancing, please come at 6; 6:30, 7 or 7:30 to view the exhibit. brookdalecc.edu

Chris Ruggiero, 7:30 p.m.Thursday, Oct. 1, Strand Center for the Arts, 400 Clifton Ave., Lakewood. www.facebook.com/StrandNJ. Ruggiero will sing hits from the '50s and '60s, plus a few of his own, from the stage of the empty Strand. Watch via Facebook.com/StrandNJ.

FOCI Photography Exhibit: 6 to 8 p.m. Friday, Sept. 25, Oyster Point Hotel, 146 Bodman Place, Red Bank. Free. Curated by Ellen Martin. It contains 30 photographs from nine photographers: eight from New Jersey and one from New York City. "In this exhibit, I want to show how many photographers are looking forward, but some are also looking back," says Martin. In order to respect social distancing, please come at 6, 6:30, 7 or 7:30 to view the exhibit. The hotel is unable to serve food and drink to a standing gathering, but dining is open at the Hotel's Pearl restaurant. 732-530-8200 to reserve a table.

Let the Chips Fall Where They May: A COVID Play: 7:15 p.m. Oct. 5, Facebook and YouTube, presented by Out of the Box Theatrics (OOTB) and Holmdel Theatre Company. Free, but donations are encouraged. Set in the near future, "Let the Chips Fall Where They May takes place in an America where there’s finally a COVID vaccine. Slowly, the nation reopens, but not without consequence. Live-streamed on OOTB's Facebook page and YouTube channels. holmdeltheatrecompany.org

Max Major — Remote Control: A Mind Reading Experiment Live on Zoom: 8 p.m., Thursday, Oct. 1, streaming on the State Theatre's website, stnj.org. Family-friendly interactive Zoom experience remotely controls the viewers' actions and predicts their thoughts live through the powers of hypnosis and mentalism. Major has appeared on the "Today" show and was a semifinalist on this season's "America's Got Talent." Capacity is limited to 40 passes per performance (each ticket allows viewing on one device). The intrigue kicks off before the show when viewers receive a TOP SECRET package in the mail. It must remain sealed until the show begins. To receive the package, orders must be placed six days prior to the event. njpac.org/event/max-major-remote-control-a-mindreading-experiment/

Milk & Cookies, State Theatre New Jersey, storytelling series for children ages 3 to 10 and their families. The series kicks off on Saturday, Oct. 24, with Charlotte Blake Alston; followed by musician Joanie Leeds on Nov. 14. To participate, a minimum donation of $10 per event is required. Patrons who donate will receive an email the day of the event at 10 a.m. with a link to watch the performance. The video can be viewed at any time and will be active from through Dec. 23 (for Alston) and Feb. 14, 2021 (for Leeds). stnj.org.

Montclair Film Festival. More than 100 feature films and shorts, plus special online presentations, will be presented in a mix of formats between Oct. 16 and 25. Some 15 features will be presented in an ad hoc "drive-in theater" in West Orange; others will be streamed. Tickets for the festival go on sale Oct. 5 for festival members, Oct. 8 for the general public. montclairfilm.org

New Jersey Friends of Clearwater festival: Saturday, Sept. 26 and Sunday, Sept. 27, https://www.njclearwater.org/festival.html. The New Jersey Friends of Clearwater's annual festival of music and advocacy makes its online debut. Jersey artists will be raising their voices in support of Clearwater — Bob Killian, Reggie Harris, the Nick Clemons Band, Papa John and the Wag — as the festival meets folks directly in their homes to address the pressing environmental issues of the day, such as the dangers of single-use plastics, rising sea levels and the need to vote. njclearwater.org/

New Jersey Film Festival: Through Sunday, Oct. 25. The New Jersey Film Festival, historically hosted on the New Brunswick campus of Rutgers University, moved its fall 2020 screenings online. The festival is presented by the Rutgers Film Co-op/New Jersey Media Arts Center in association with the Rutgers University Program in Cinema Studies and runs through Sunday, Oct. 25, via Eventive, with more than 40 screenings. Tickets are $12 for 24-hour access to individual online screenings, with festival passes available for $100. njfilmfest.com

New Jersey Repertory Company: Beyond the Curtain Video Series features artists reflecting on their work with the Long Branch-based theater. Among them: playwrights Chloé Hung and Richard Strand, and director Lisa James. The museum also created the West End Virtual Museum of Art. The inaugural exhibit "Valor & Victory: The Art of the Soldier" features the artist Quinton Greene. Although the museum is virtual, the paintings are real and available for purchase. NJ Rep is also part of a five-theater organization that formed #Theatre5Alliance. The aim is to bring the arts to people's homes and to highlight the importance of keeping local theater alive and thriving. The alliance hopes to harness the writing talents of dozens of well-known film, television and stage actors to create original vignettes of approximately 5 to 10 minutes each. Currently, there are six videos (by Joe Mantegna, Tony Shalhoub, Jodi Long, Kim Brockington, Alfred Molina and James Pickens Jr). More information is at njrep.org

Outdoor Return to Boheme - Strings Style: 2 to 5 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 25, Diamond's Restaurant, 69 Route 156, Yardville (just north of Route 130), presented by The Boheme Opera NJ Guild, $55. A string trio featuring members of the Boheme Opera NJ Orchestra will perform Classical, opera, Broadway and pop music. Guests will also enjoy authentic Italian light fare. Coffee, tea and soft drinks will be provided. Guests are welcome to BYOB. Masks are required when not eating. Seating is limited. Reservations and advanced payment are required by Oct. 18. Please include the name of each guest. Mail checks payable to: Boheme Opera NJ Guild, P. O. Box 9165, Trenton, NJ 08650. Info: BONJGUILD@gmail.com or call Joan Hoagland at 609-208-2171; bohemeopera.com

Premier in the Park: A Fall Festival of the Arts, presented by The Premier Theatre Company, outdoor performance on Oct. 24 at the Middletown Arts Center, 36 Church St., Middletown. The event begins at 2 p.m. with local band Jimmy Shoez and the Magooz, then Premier performances at 3 (from Broadway shows to classic comedy routines). Patrons can purchase a circle that accommodates up to six people. Tickets for the circle are $60 for two patrons. Up to four additional patrons can be added for $10 each. Proceeds will be shared by The Premier Theatre Company and the Middletown Arts Center. COVID-19 rules will be strictly adhered to. The No Limits Cafe in Middletown will be offering fresh baked cookies packages with all proceeds going to the Cafe, which is staffed by special needs adults in Middletown. Premier also will be collecting food for Lunch Break at the performance. Patrons are asked to bring canned or boxed nonperishable food items. Tickets and cookie orders must be made in advance online. Premier face masks are also available to order. Bring your own chair/blanket. Rain date will be Sunday, Oct. 25. To purchase tickets and for more information, visit premiertheatre.com.

Regina Carter, She'll be live — but not in person — at Newark's NJPAC this fall, streaming on Sept. 22. So will Suzanne Vega (Oct. 7), and Sarah Brightman (Nov. 27). It's all part of "Live at Home" series presented by Newark's NJPAC. njpac.org

The Rave-Ons, 7:30 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 26, Surflight Theatre, 201 Engleside Ave,. Beach Haven. surflight.org. The Rave-Ons, known for their Buddy Holly tribute, will play a night of '50s and '60s rock. surflight.org

Rutgers Jewish Film Festival: Nov. 8 to 22. Opening film "Aulcie," Nov. 8, is the story of basketball legend Aulcie Perry. A Newark native turned Israeli citizen, Perry put Israel on the map as a member of the Maccabi Tel Aviv team in the 1970s. Opening night will feature a Q&A with Dani Menkin, director of this new documentary film, at 5:30 p.m. All tickets are $10. All access pass is $90. For more information, speaker schedule and instructions on the new virtual format, visit BildnerCenter.Rutgers.edu/film.

Two River Rising: An Online Benefit Reading Series: "Romeo and Juliet," a modern verse translation from South Korean playwright Hansol Jung, Sept. 30 and Oct. 1, part of Two River Theater's online benefit reading series that will feature reimagined classics to world premieres. $25 per reading, which includes access to live post-reading Q&As with the artists involved, hosted on Zoom. Online ticket sales will close four hours prior to event time. Tickets can be purchased from 3 to 7 p.m. on the day of the event by calling the box office at 732-345-1400. Ticket buyers will be emailed a link to access each reading, three hours prior to the event’s start time. Issues signing on? Call the box office or email info@trtc.org. For more information on the series or the Red Bank-based theater, visit tworivertheater.org

Sundays on St. John’s: Cranston Dean with Jackson Pines and Rachel A. Dobken, 2 p.m., Sunday, Sept. 27. Bobby Bandiera and Friends, 3 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 4, Sundays. Sandy Mack Band and Friends with Stringbean and the Stalkers, 3 p.m. .Sunday, Oct 11. Glen Burtnik and Friends with Emily Grove, 3 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 18. The A Very Asbury Holiday Show! All-Star Band featuring Tony Perruso, Jillian Rhys McCoy, the Eddie Testa Band, the Anthony Krizan Band and more, 3 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 25. St. John's Island, Sunset Lake, Asbury Park. asburyparkmusiclives.org/stjohns

Suzanne Vega: 9 p.m. Wednesday, Oct. 7, streaming on the State Theatre and Count Basie Center for the Arts websites, $20. STNJ.org and thebasie.org. Show performed live from the Blue Note for an at-home live-stream of her hit show "An Evening of New York Songs and Stories."

William Paterson University's Jazz Room Series at Home Live-Streamed Concerts: All performances live-streamed in Shea Center at William Paterson University in Wayne. Ticket prices are "pay what you want," $10 to $25, $8 for students who do not attend William Paterson and the university community, free for the university's students with a weekly code emailed from faculty. Tickets must be purchased in advance. Included in the series: Ed Neumeister Quartet, 4 p.m. Oct. 18 and Veronica Swift at 4 p.m. Nov. 22. A complete schedule is at wpunj.edu/wppresents/jazz-room-series/index.html. Sittin' In Meet–the–Artist sessions are one hour (3 pm) prior to each concert. Submit questions in advance to: jazzroom@wpunj.edu. To receive up-to-date information about the Jazz Room Series at Home concerts, visit https://secure.wpunj.edu/wplive/mailinglist.cfm

The Work of Adrienne Kennedy: Inspiration & Influence: Nov. 14 to Dec. 12, virtual play festival from McCarter Theatre in association with Round House Theatre. Adrienne Kennedy is one of the most prolific and widely studied living playwrights. Despite her outsized influence, Kennedy is not a household name. This digital festival is a celebration of why she should be. For a schedule, visit mccarter.org. Tickets will be available soon. mccarter.org

search_result.title: The stories behind Old Town Fort Collins' ghost signs
search_result.text:
There are ghosts lurking in Old Town Fort Collins.

Some are barely there, lingering on alley walls. Others are two stories tall, practically screaming at you as you round the corner into Old Town Square.

Are they apparitions? Not quite. Most are advertisements — painted "ghost" signs that once marked where Fort Collins' long-gone local businesses stood.

search_result.title: Delaware Baseball Hall of Fame inductees include former Phillies
search_result.text:
Two former major leaguers and several former William Penn High and University of Delaware players are among the seven 2023 Delaware Baseball Hall of Fame inductees.

Matt Brainard, Bill Brakeley, Rob Bryson, Brian Lesher, Johnny Morris, Mark Romanczuk and Mark Rubini will be recognized before the Wilmington Blue Rocks play the Jersey Shore Blue Claws in a South Atlantic League game June 14 at Frawley Stadium.

The Delaware Baseball Hall of Fame was founded in 1994 and is operated by the Delaware High School Baseball Coaches Association. The Class of 2023’s enshrinement increases the number of inductees to 157 along with seven teams. A plaque on the wall outside the first-base side of the pressbox at Frawley Stadium lists all the inductees.

The seven 2023 inductees:

Matt Brainard

Brainard starred in football, wrestling and baseball at William Penn, where he set a school stolen base mark and sparked the Colonials to the 1989 state title game. Brainard was then a four-year starter and three-time NAIA All-American at Wilmington University, which reached the 1992 NAIA World Series and won three conference and regional titles. Brainard played two minor-league seasons in the Phillies organization before becoming a coach. He became Wilmington coach at age 23 and guided the Wildcats for 10 seasons through 2004, winning 350 games, seven conference or section titles, three regional championships and making the 1995 NAIA World Series. He was seven-time conference and three-time regional Coach of the Year. Brainard then moved to West Chester for two years, steering the Golden Rams to two Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference East titles and the 2006 NCAA East Region championship, resulting in West Chester’s first Division II World Series berth.

Bill Brakeley

The hard-throwing lefty from Connecticut was first-team All-State his final two years at St. Andrew’s School in 1985 and 1986 while setting school records for career wins (20), career strikeouts (287) and strikeouts in a game (18, twice). He started and won two games, including the championship, for Delaware in the inaugural Carpenter Cup at Veterans Stadium. Brakeley then starred at the University of Delaware in 1988 and 1989, setting a school record with 12.8 strikeouts per nine innings. He was a fourth-round draft choice of the Milwaukee Brewers and played three minor-league seasons.

Rob Bryson

Bryson was a first-team All-State pitcher his junior and senior years, 2005 and 2006, at William Penn. A four-year starter who also played shortstop, Bryson batted .322 and went 22-8 with a 1.27 earned run average and 269 strikeouts in 198 innings in his career. He was a Collegiate Baseball/Louisville Slugger first-team All-American as a senior when he batted .390 and went 9-2 with a 1.01 ERA and 117 strikeouts in 69 innings. Bryson attended Seminole State Community College in Florida before pitching nine professional seasons in which he struck out 525 in 434 innings and reached as high as Triple-A in the Cleveland system.

Brian Lesher

Lesher starred in basketball and baseball at Newark, where he was the first-team All-State first baseman as a senior in 1989, before going to the University of Delaware. Lesher was a two-time first-team all-conference pick with the Blue Hens as an outfielder/first baseman and a three-year starter from 1990-92, including the 1992 NCAA Tournament qualifiers. He batted .381, .380 and .376 those three seasons. Lesher was a 25th-round pick in the 1992 draft by Oakland and batted .283 in 12 minor-league seasons. He also had 288 big-league plate appearances in 108 games with Oakland, Seattle and Toronto (2002) and smacked nine homers.

Johnny Morris

Morris starred in football, basketball and baseball at the old Lewes High from 1958-60 The lefty’s baseball exploits included 20 wins, 351 strikeouts and three no-hitters. He also batted .588 with six home runs as a senior and was signed by the Phillies. Morris reached the big leagues in 1966 with Philadelphia and ended up pitching in 132 games over eight seasons and going 11-7 with a 3.95 ERA for the Phillies, Orioles, Seattle Pilots, Brewers and Giants.

Mark Romanczuk

One of Delaware’s most dominant high school pitchers, Romanczuk was second-team All-State as a St. Mark’s sophomore in 2000 and a first-team choice the next two years. He twice struck out 18 in a game, set school records for strikeouts in a season (146) and career (315) and had a career ERA of 0.77. His four no-hitters included a perfect game in which he whiffed 17. Romanczuk was drafted in the fifth round pick by Tampa Bay but elected to attend Stanford. He was Collegiate Baseball Freshman of the Year in 2003 after going 12-2 with a 4.01 ERA and 80 strikeouts in 112 innings as Stanford reached the College World Series title game. Romanczuk was a third-team All-American going 11-3 with a 4.31 ERA and 94 strikeouts in 109 innings as a sophomore. He was drafted in the fourth round by Arizona in 2005 and pitched four pro seasons.

Mark Rubini

Rubini was a speedy, hard-hitting outfielder who starred at William Penn and the University of Delaware. He was first-team All-State as a Colonials senior in 1983, when he batted .455, drove in 15 runs and stole nine bases. His career batting average was .451. Rubini was equally troublesome for opposing pitchers at Delaware from 1984-87, when he was a three-time All-East Coast Conference pick. He graduated first on the UD career chart in stolen bases (88), sixth in home runs (35), 10th in runs scored (196) and 15th with a .370 batting average. He batted a team-leading .423 as a sophomore and .421 as a junior. Rubini was a 35th-round draft pick after his junior year by Milwaukee but never played professionally.

search_result.title: Mench, Simpson, Eaton among Sports Hall of Fame inductees
search_result.text:
Kevin Tresolini

The News Journal

A big-league baseball player, Delaware’s only National Hockey Leaguer and one of the state's winningest high school football coaches are among 10 who’ll be enshrined in the Delaware Sports Hall of Fame during its May 16 induction banquet.

Former St. Mark’s High and University of Delaware slugger Kevin Mench, Dickinson High graduate Mark Eaton, who played 13 NHL seasons, and Butch Simpson, who guided Newark High to nine state football titles, will be joined by long-time Tower Hill track and cross country coach Bob Behr; former Caravel Academy multi-sport standout Kristin Mills Caldwell; successful Caesar Rodney High coach John Coveleski; former Archmere baseball and basketball coach Vince Filliben; Olympic figure skater Scott Gregory; tennis official Lois Huggins; and world champion race walker Jack Starr.

HIGH SCHOOLS: Maull decides to stay at St. Georges

search_result.title: Dover grad Spadafino pitching in for Blue Hens
search_result.text:
NEWARK – Nick Spadafino could have played baseball in places where there are palm trees and winter warmth.

The Dover High graduate chose to stay near home and play for the University of Delaware, continuing a trend that has long been a hallmark of the Blue Hens’ baseball success.

More than any other UD athletic team, Delaware baseball has harvested the First State for talent.

When Spadafino, the starting pitcher in the opening game of a doubleheader against Towson Friday at Hannah Stadium, limited the Tigers to two hits in six innings of a 7-5 win, he was among the latest examples.

“A lot of kids think, ‘Oh I want to go down south to these big schools.’ ” said Spadafino, who was also a standout wide receiver, quarterback and punter on Dover’s football team and played basketball.

“I don’t know, I’ve just kind of taken pride and honor in the fact that I came to these games when I was younger and now I get to put on the uniform.”

EAGLES: Rookies may be needed right away

HIGH SCHOOLS: Tower Hill soccer player aids amputees

St. Mark’s High grad Calvin Scott had three of the Blue Hens’ 12 hits, including a home run, in the opener. Cape Henlopen High grad Diaz Nardo, Delaware’s starting third baseman, had one of those hits.

Wilmington Charter grad Kyle Baker joined Scott and Nardo in the starting lineup in the second game of the twinbill, though Baker later left with an injury in the Hens’ 11-1 win. Scott extended his hitting streak to 17 games and raised his average to .351 with three more hits.

Delaware (27-20, 12-8) clinched a CAA Tournament berth with the sweep and will close the series against Towson (19-31, 5-15) with a single-game Sunday.

“I just loved coming in knowing I played against this guy, and now we get to play together,” Spadafino said of his in-state comrades. “They did well against me and it’s nice to have them on my side.”

Spadafino was recruited by the likes of South Florida and Western Carolina.

“One thing that was big for me was my family getting to see me play,” said Spadafino, referring to mom Janice, a UD grad, and dad Joe, a former Eastern Kentucky football standout who is Newark’s parks and recreation director.

“I know this program is trying to take that next step to be one of the top-tier teams in the CAA. You can just look at this beautiful stadium [with its all-turf field] and see the money they’ve put into it . . . The guys from Delaware who were here when I was being recruited told me they loved playing close to home and that’s what sold me and I’ve loved every minute.”

One of those players was Chad Kuhl, the Middletown High grad now in the Pittsburgh Pirates rotation. Kuhl is among many ex-Blue Hen standouts with First State roots, such as former Phillies pitcher and manager Dallas Green (Conrad) and Kevin Mench (St. Mark’s), the eight-year major-leaguer who’ll be inducted to the Delaware Sports Hall of Fame on Tuesday. Other Hens from Delaware high schools who reached the big leagues were Wilmington High’s Al Neiger, William Penn’s Cliff Brumbaugh and Newark’s Brian Lesher, while numerous others had minor-league success.

Delaware coach Jim Sherman, a standout third baseman with the Blue Hens from 1979-82 who reached Triple-A in the Houston Astros’ system, is a William Penn grad. Bob Hannah, Blue Hen coach from 1965-2000, said while watching Friday’s games that recruiting Delaware players became a necessity because of economics – Delaware didn’t offer scholarships and expenses were considerably lower for in-state students – and the state had some talent.

“We want every Delaware kid,” Sherman said, “that, one, has the talent level to play at this level and, two, which is most difficult, can get into Delaware academically . . . I take pride in it, being a Delaware kid myself. We can find some really good kids here in Delaware and because we’re a small state we can maybe see them more.”

Spadafino is 5-3 with a 5.02 ERA on the season. He moved into the No. 1 starting spot after Brandon Walter, the sophomore out of Hodgson Vo-Tech, came up with elbow trouble that has ended his season. It’s not known yet if surgery will be needed. Ron Marinaccio, last year’s No. 1 starter who had gone into the bullpen this season, has returned to the starting rotation and won the second game Friday, allowing two hits in seven innings.

“It’s obviously a big loss when you lose an arm like that, especially him being a Friday guy,” Spadafino said of Walter. “I just tried to keep the same mindset. You’re going against the same team whether it’s Friday or Saturday. But the pressure does pick up a little bit because you kind of want to get off to a good start for the weekend, especially knowing you only have to win one more to win the series.”

Relying on a two-seam sinker, slider and change-up, Spadafino depends on control rather than knee-buckling velocity.

“That’s how he’s gotta throw,” said Sherman, who liked how Spadafino “gutted it out” on Friday.

Last season, Spadafino had gone 5-3 with a 7.01 ERA while being used in every possible role, as a starter, closer and long reliever. Coaches told him he’d be given a shot to start this year, and pitching last summer in the Coastal Plains Summer League for the Petersburg Generals provided adequate preparation.

“I think that experience last season really helped me,” Spadafino said. “Coach Sherm told me when you go to summer ball, just work on what you’re gonna do to start. That allowed me to work getting in the strike zone more, developing my changeup and my slider. It really gave me the confidence they were gonna believe in me.”
